Stage2_Summary_Compressed:
On 2022-02-16, patient's headache improved, but fever persisted. Blood cultures were drawn, and patient was started on ceftriaxone 2g IV q12h and azithromycin 500mg PO q24h. 

On 2022-02-17, patient's fever resolved, and blood cultures grew methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). Patient was switched to vancomycin 1g IV q12h. 

On 2022-02-18, patient's headache and fever recurred. Patient was started on dexamethasone 4mg PO q6h and cefazolin 1g IV q8h.

Stage2_Summary_Compressed: The patient, a 65-year-old male, was admitted on 2022-02-15 with a chief complaint of chest pain. He was treated with aspirin 325mg and clopidogrel 75mg daily. On admission, his vital signs were: blood pressure 180/90 mmHg, heart rate 110 beats per minute, and oxygen saturation 92% on room air. Laboratory results showed: troponin 0.5 ng/mL, creatine kinase 150 IU/L, and white blood cell count 12,000 cells/μL. The patient underwent an urgent coronary angiogram, which revealed a 90% occlusion of the left anterior descending artery. He was subsequently treated with percutaneous coronary intervention and stenting. The patient's condition improved, and he was discharged on 2022-02-20.

Stage2_Summary_Compressed: A 65-year-old male presented to the emergency department on 2022-02-15 with a 2-day history of worsening chest pain. He reported a 3-day history of fever, cough, and difficulty breathing. His medications included aspirin 81mg daily and metoprolol 25mg twice daily. His vital signs were: blood pressure 120/80mmHg, pulse 100bpm, respiratory rate 24/min, oxygen saturation 88% on room air, and temperature 38.5°C. Laboratory results showed a white blood cell count of 15,000 cells/μL, hemoglobin 12.5g/dL, and C-reactive protein 120mg/L. Chest X-ray revealed bilateral infiltrates. The patient was diagnosed with community-acquired pneumonia and acute bronchitis. He was treated with azithromycin 500mg PO daily for 7 days, ceftriaxone 2g IV daily for 3 days, and oxygen therapy. The patient was admitted to the hospital for further management.

Stage2_Summary_Compressed: The patient, a 65-year-old male, presented to the emergency department on 2023-02-15 with a 2-day history of chest pain and shortness of breath. He was treated with aspirin 325mg and metoprolol 25mg IV. His vital signs were: blood pressure 180/90 mmHg, heart rate 120 bpm, respiratory rate 24 breaths/min, and oxygen saturation 88% on room air. Laboratory results showed troponin 0.5 ng/mL, creatine kinase 150 IU/L, and white blood cell count 12,000 cells/μL. The patient underwent an electrocardiogram, which revealed ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVL. He was diagnosed with non-ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) and was admitted to the cardiology service.

Stage2_Summary_Compressed: Patient was admitted on 2022-02-15 with a 2-day history of worsening headache, fever, and confusion. On admission, vital signs were: temperature 38.5°C, blood pressure 120/80 mmHg, pulse 100 beats per minute, and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. The patient was prescribed acetaminophen 325mg PO q6h for headache and ceftriaxone 2g IV q12h for suspected meningitis. Laboratory results showed white blood cell count 15,000 cells/μL, hemoglobin 12.5g/dL, and C-reactive protein 120 mg/L. The patient underwent lumbar puncture on 2022-02-16, which revealed cloudy cerebrospinal fluid with 1000 white blood cells/μL. The patient was diagnosed with bacterial meningitis and was started on vancomycin 1g IV q12h.

Stage2_Summary_Compressed: Patient presented with fever, headache, and neck stiffness on 2023-02-10. Vital signs: temperature 38.5°C, blood pressure 120/80 mmHg, pulse 100 beats per minute, and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. Medications included acetaminophen 325mg PO QID and metoclopramide 10mg PO QID. Lab results showed white blood cell count 12,000 cells/μL, hemoglobin 12.5g/dL, and C-reactive protein 10mg/L. Diagnosis was made of probable meningitis. Patient underwent lumbar puncture on 2023-02-11, with cerebrospinal fluid analysis revealing 500 white blood cells/μL and 1000 red blood cells/μL. Patient was started on ceftriaxone 2g IV Q12h and vancomycin 1g IV Q12h, with plans for further antibiotic therapy and follow-up.

Stage2_Summary_Compressed: A 65-year-old male was admitted for chest pain. On admission, his blood pressure was 180/90 mmHg, heart rate was 110 beats per minute, and oxygen saturation was 92% on room air. He was prescribed aspirin 325mg and clopidogrel 75mg daily. A stat electrocardiogram showed ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVL. Troponin levels were elevated at 12.5 ng/mL. The patient underwent urgent coronary angioplasty with stenting of the left anterior descending artery. He was also given intravenous heparin 5000 units every 12 hours and aspirin 325mg daily. On hospital day 2, his blood pressure was 140/80 mmHg, heart rate was 90 beats per minute, and oxygen saturation was 98% on room air. His troponin levels decreased to 2.5 ng/mL. He was discharged on hospital day 3 with a diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction and was prescribed clopidogrel 75mg daily for 12 months.

The patient's condition improved, and they were discharged on 2022-02-20.

mesh discharge condition discharge instructions dear mr you were admitted to the hospital after a laparoscopic proctocolectomy wend ileostomy and parastomal mesh placement for surgical management of your ulcerative colitis with multifocal highgrade dysplasia you have recovered from this procedure and you are now ready to return home you have a new ileostomy and stool no longer passes through the colon so your output will be liquid the most common complication from an ileostomy is dehydration you must measure your ileostomy output for the next few weeks please bring your io sheet to your postop appointment the output should be no less than cc or greater than cc per day if you find that your output has become too much or too little please call the office please monitor for signs and symptoms of dehydration if you notice these symptoms please call the office or go to the emergency room you will need to keep yourself well hydrated if you notice your ileostomy output increasing drink liquids with electrolytes such as gatorade please monitor the appearance of your stoma and care for it as instructed by the ostomy nurses you notice that the stoma is turning darker blue or purple please call the office or go to the emergency room the stoma may ooze small amounts of blood at times when touched which will improve over time monitor the skin around the stoma for any bulging or signs of infection you will follow up with the ostomy nurses in the clinic weeks after surgery you will also have a visiting nurse at home for the next few weeks to help to monitor your ostomy you have laparoscopic surgical incisions on your abdomen which are closed with internal sutures it is important that you monitor these areas for signs and symptoms of infection including increasing redness of the incision lines whitegreenyellowfoul smelling drainage increased pain at the incision increased warmth of the skin at the incision or swelling of the area you may shower pat the incisions dry with a towel do not rub if you have steristrips they will fall off over time please do not remove them please do not take a bath or swim until cleared by the surgical team pain is expected after surgery this will gradually improve over the first week or so you are home you should continue to take extra strength tylenol for pain every hours around the clock please do not take more than mg of tylenol in hours or any other medications that contain tylenol such as cold medication do not drink alcohol while taking tylenol you may also take advil mg every hours for days please take advil with food if these medications are not controlling your pain to a point where you can ambulate and perform minor tasks you should take a dose of the narcotic pain medication tramadol please do not take sedating medications drink alcohol or drive while taking the narcotic pain medication you will be going home with your jp drain which will be removed at your postop visit please look at the site every day for signs of infection maintain suction of the bulb note color consistency and amount of fluid in the drain call the doctor nurse practitioner or nurse if the amount increases significantly or changes in character be sure to empty the drain as needed and record output you may shower wash the area gently with warm soapy water keep the insertion site clean and dry otherwise avoid swimming baths hot tubs do not submerge yourself in water make sure to keep the drain attached securely to your body to prevent pulling or dislocation you may feel weak or washed out for up to weeks after surgery do not lift greater than a gallon of milk for weeks at your post op appointment your surgical team will clear you for heavier exercise in the meantime you may climb stairs and go outside and walk please avoid traveling long distances until you speak with your surgical team at your postop visit thank you for allowing us to participate in your care we wish you all the best sincerely your care team

Stage2_Summary_Compressed: A 65-year-old male patient was admitted to the hospital on March 10, 2022, with a 2-day history of worsening chest pain and shortness of breath. He was taking metoprolol 25mg daily and aspirin 81mg daily. On admission, his vital signs were: blood pressure 160/90 mmHg, pulse 110 beats per minute, respiratory rate 20 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation 88% on room air. Laboratory results showed a troponin level of 0.5 ng/mL, creatine kinase (CK) 250 IU/L, and a white blood cell count of 12,000 cells/μL. The patient underwent an emergency coronary angiogram, which revealed a 90% occlusion of the left anterior descending artery. He was treated with a stent placement and received 325mg of aspirin and 75mg of clopidogrel daily.

Stage2_Summary_Compressed: A 65-year-old male was admitted to the hospital with a 3-day history of worsening chest pain and shortness of breath. He was prescribed metoprolol 25mg PO BID and aspirin 81mg PO daily. On admission, his blood pressure was 180/90 mmHg, heart rate was 110 bpm, and oxygen saturation was 92% on room air. Laboratory results showed a troponin level of 0.5 ng/mL, creatine kinase (CK) 150 IU/L, and a white blood cell count (WBC) of 12,000 cells/μL. The patient underwent an urgent coronary angiogram, which revealed a 90% occlusion of the left anterior descending artery. He was treated with a stent placement and continued on metoprolol 25mg PO BID, aspirin 81mg PO daily, and clopidogrel 75mg PO daily. His blood pressure decreased to 140/80 mmHg on hospital day 3, and his WBC count decreased to 8,000 cells/μL. The patient was discharged on hospital day 5 with a diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction and was scheduled for follow-up in 2

Stage2_Summary_Compressed: A 65-year-old male presented to the emergency department on 2022-02-10 with a 2-day history of chest pain and shortness of breath. He was treated with aspirin 325mg and metoprolol 25mg IV. His vital signs were: blood pressure 180/90mmHg, heart rate 120bpm, oxygen saturation 88% on room air, and respiratory rate 20/min. Laboratory results showed troponin 0.5ng/mL, creatine kinase 150IU/L, and white blood cell count 12,000/mm3. The patient underwent urgent coronary angioplasty with stenting of the left anterior descending artery. He was diagnosed with acute myocardial infarction and was admitted to the intensive care unit for further management.

Stage2_Summary_Compressed: A 75-year-old male was admitted with a 2-day history of chest pain and shortness of breath. On admission, his blood pressure was 180/100 mmHg, heart rate 120 beats per minute, and oxygen saturation 88% on room air. He was treated with aspirin 325mg and clopidogrel 75mg daily. Electrocardiogram (ECG) showed ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVL. Troponin level was 12 ng/mL (normal range 0-14 ng/mL). He underwent urgent coronary angioplasty with stenting of the left anterior descending artery. His blood pressure decreased to 140/80 mmHg after the procedure. He was discharged on day 3 with a diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction and was prescribed metoprolol 25mg twice daily and atorvastatin 40mg daily.

Stage2_Summary_Compressed: A 65-year-old male presented to the emergency department on 02/10/2023 with a 2-day history of severe chest pain. He was treated with aspirin 325mg and clopidogrel 75mg. His vital signs were: blood pressure 180/90 mmHg, pulse 110 beats per minute, and oxygen saturation 92% on room air. Laboratory results showed troponin 0.5 ng/mL, creatine kinase 250 IU/L, and white blood cell count 12,000 cells/μL. The patient underwent an electrocardiogram, which revealed ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVL. He was diagnosed with non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) and underwent urgent coronary angioplasty with stenting of the left anterior descending artery.

Stage2_Summary_Compressed: A 65-year-old male was admitted with a 2-day history of worsening chest pain and shortness of breath. He was prescribed aspirin 325mg PO daily and metoprolol 25mg PO BID. On admission, his vital signs were: blood pressure 180/90 mmHg, heart rate 110 bpm, respiratory rate 20/min, and oxygen saturation 92% on room air. Laboratory results showed: troponin 0.5 ng/mL, creatine kinase 150 IU/L, and white blood cell count 12,000 cells/μL. The patient underwent an emergency coronary angioplasty with stenting of the left anterior descending artery. He was diagnosed with non-ST elevation myocardial infarction and was transferred to the intensive care unit for further management.

Stage2_Summary_Compressed: Patient was admitted on 02/10/2023 with a 2-day history of severe headache, fever, and stiff neck. Vital signs: BP 120/80 mmHg, HR 100 bpm, T 38.5°C (101.3°F), RR 20 breaths/min. CT scan revealed a 5mm abscess in the left frontal lobe. Patient was started on ceftriaxone 2g IV q12h and metronidazole 500mg PO q8h. On 02/12/2023, patient's headache improved, but fever persisted. Lab results: WBC 15,000/mm³, Hgb 12g/dL, Hct 35%. On 02/14/2023, patient underwent craniotomy and abscess drainage. Post-op, patient was continued on ceftriaxone and metronidazole for 4 weeks.

Stage2_Summary_Compressed: A 75-year-old male patient was admitted with a 2-day history of chest pain and shortness of breath. On admission, his vital signs were: blood pressure 180/90 mmHg, heart rate 120 beats per minute, and oxygen saturation 88% on room air. He was treated with aspirin 325mg and clopidogrel 75mg daily. ECG showed ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVL. Troponin levels were elevated at 12.5 ng/mL. The patient underwent urgent coronary angioplasty with stenting of the left anterior descending artery. He was also started on metoprolol 25mg twice daily and lisinopril 20mg daily. His blood pressure decreased to 140/80 mmHg on hospital day 3. On hospital day 5, his troponin levels decreased to 2.5 ng/mL. The patient was discharged on hospital day 7 with a diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction and was advised to follow up with his cardiologist in 2 weeks.

Stage2_Summary_Compressed: Patient presented to the emergency department on 2022-02-15 with a 2-day history of severe headache, fever, and stiff neck. On examination, temperature was 38.5°C (101.3°F), blood pressure was 120/80 mmHg, and pulse was 100 beats per minute. CT scan revealed a large left-sided subdural hematoma. Patient was started on dexamethasone 4mg IV every 6 hours and aspirin 325mg PO daily. Lab results showed a white blood cell count of 15,000/μL and a platelet count of 150,000/μL. Patient underwent emergency craniotomy and evacuation of the hematoma on 2022-02-16. Postoperatively, patient was started on warfarin 5mg PO daily and was discharged on 2022-02-20 with a plan for follow-up in 1 week.
Target_Summary: the patient was brought to the operating room on where the patient underwent aortic root enlargement with bovine pericardial patch and aortic valve replacement with a mm ease pericardial tissue valve overall the patient tolerated the procedure well and postoperatively was transferred to the cvicu in stable condition for recovery and invasive monitoring pod found the patient extubated alert and oriented and breathing comfortably the patient was neurologically intact and hemodynamically stable beta blocker was initiated the patient was transferred to the telemetry floor for further recovery chest tubes and pacing wires were discontinued without complication the patient was transfused with units of rbcs for acute blood loss anemia there was no concern for hemorrhage and the patients hematocrit responded appropriately she was started on iron supplementation on pod the patient developed acute respiratory distress and was transferred to the icu she was placed on bipap with improvement of her dyspnea a cxr showed volume overload and she was placed on iv lasix she developed atrial fibrillation and was started on amiodarone with diuresis her sob resolved and she was transferred back to the floor her discharge cxr shows small bilateral pleural effusions and she will be discharged on a day course of lasix the patient was evaluated by the speech pathology team due to concern for aspiration she was deemed to be deconditioned and she will be discharged tolerating a nectar thick liquid and regular solid diet the patient was evaluated by the physical therapy service for assistance with strength and mobility and was deemed appropriate for rehab by the time of discharge on pod the patient was ambulating freely the wound was healing and pain was controlled with oral analgesics the patient was discharged to rehab in in good condition with appropriate follow up instructions

diagnosis rectal cancer discharge condition discharge instructions dear mr you were admitted to the hospital after a laparoscopic low anterior resection to treat your rectal cancer samples of tissue were taken and the pathology results were reviewed with you during your hospitilization due to the high volume output of your new ileostomy you were trialed on new medications after several weeks you were taken back to the or to have an ileostomy reversal you have recovered from this procedure well and you are now ready to return home you are tolerating a regular diet passing gas and your pain is controlled with pain medications by mouth please monitor your bowel function closely you may or may not have had a bowel movement prior to discharge which is acceptable however it is important that you have a bowel movement in the next days after anesthesia it is not uncommon for patients to have some decrease in bowel function but you should not have prolonged constipation some loose stool and passing of small amounts of dark old appearing blood are expected however if you notice that you are passing bright red blood with bowel movements or having large amounts of loose stool without improvement please call the office or go to the emergency room while taking narcotic pain medications you are at risk for constipation please take an over the counter stool softener such as colace and if the symptoms do not improve call the office if you are passing loose stool without improvement please call the office or go to the emergency room if you are having symptoms of dehydration headache lightheadedness dizziness dark urine or dry mouth while taking narcotic pain medications there is a risk that you will have some constipation please take an over the counter stool softener such as colace and if the symptoms does not improve call the office it is also not uncommon after an ileostomy takedown to have frequent loose stools until you are taking more regular food however this should improve the muscles of the sphincters have not been used in quite some time and you may experience urgency or small amounts of incontinence however this should improve if you do not see improvement in these symptoms within days please call the office if you experience any of the following symptoms please call the office or go to the emergency room increasing abdominal distension increasing abdominal pain nausea vomiting inability to tolerate food or liquids prolonged loose stool or constipation you have a small wound where the old ileostomy once was this should be covered with a dry sterile gauze dressing please monitor the incision for signs and symptoms of infection including increasing redness and pain at the incision site draining of whitegreenyellowfoul smelling drainage or if you develop a fever if you develop these symptoms please call the office or go to the emergency room you may shower let the warm water run over the wound line and pat the area dry with a towel do not rub please apply a new gauze dressing after showering pain it is expected that you will have pain after surgery this will gradually improve over the first week or so you are home you should continue to take extra strength tylenol for pain every hours around the clock please do not take more than mg of tylenol in hours or any other medications that contain tylenol such as cold medication do not drink alcohol while taking tylenol you may also take advil mg every hours for days please take advil with food if these medications are not controlling your pain to a point where you can ambulate and perform minor tasks you should take a dose of the narcotic pain medication oxycodone please do not take sedating medications or drink alcohol while taking the narcotic pain medication do not drive while taking narcotic medications activity you may feel weak or washed out for up to weeks after surgery do not lift greater than a gallon of milk for weeks at your post op appointment your surgical team will clear you for heavier exercise in the meantime you may climb stairs and go outside and walk please avoid traveling long distances until you speak with your surgical team at your postop visit again please do not drive while taking narcotic pain medications you will be discharged home on lovenox injections to prevent blood clots after surgery you will take this for days after your surgery date please finish the entire prescription this will be given once daily please follow all nursing teaching instruction given by the nursing staff please monitor for any signs of bleeding fast heart rate bloody bowel movements abdominal pain bruising feeling faint or weak if you have any of these symptoms please call our office or seek medical attention avoid any contact activity while taking lovenox please take extra caution to avoid falling

Stage2_Summary_Compressed: A 65-year-old male presented to the emergency department on 2022-02-15 with a 2-day history of worsening chest pain and shortness of breath. He was prescribed metoprolol 25mg PO BID and aspirin 81mg PO daily for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. On admission, his vital signs were: blood pressure 180/90 mmHg, heart rate 110 bpm, respiratory rate 20 breaths/min, and oxygen saturation 92% on room air. His physical examination revealed a regular heart rhythm with a grade 2/6 systolic murmur. Laboratory results showed a troponin level of 0.5 ng/mL and a creatine kinase-MB (CK-MB) of 25 IU/L. An electrocardiogram (ECG) revealed ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVL. The patient underwent urgent coronary angioplasty with stenting of the left anterior descending artery on 2022-02-16.
Target_Summary: mr presented to holding at on for a laparoscopic low anterior resection during the procedure his ureter was severed and required a ureteral stent to be placed intraoperatively he tolerated the procedure well despite the complication after a brief and uneventful stay in the pacu the patient was transferred to the floor for further postoperative management when he arrived on the floor he failed his foley void trial and a foley catheter was replaced in his bladder over the next several days his postoperative course was further complicated by high ileostomy output he was trialed on a variety of medications to decrease his ostomy output but he continued to lose large amounts of fluid through his stoma he became hyponatremic and was treated with a high sodium diet free water restriction and iv normal saline boluses his electrolyte abnormalities slowly resolved but he continued to have high ostomy output and he was taken back to the operating room on for an ileostomy reversal he was initially kept npo after the procedure but was slowly advanced to a regular diet which he tolerated well he underwent a third foleycatheter void trial but again failed and a foley catheter was placed in his bladder during his hospitalization he remained stable from a cardiovascular standpoint and his vital signs were routinely monitored he also had good pulmonary toileting as early ambulation and incentive spirometry were encouraged throughout hospitalization he was found to have a urinary tract infection and was started on a prescription for ciprofloxacin additionally he developed a minor softtissue infection on his abdomen which resolved after a short course of keflex during his hospitalization his blood levels were checked daily to monitor for signs of bleeding the patient received subcutaneous heparin and dyne boots were used during this stay he was encouraged to get up and ambulate as early as possible the patient is being discharged on a prophylactic dose of lovenox on the patient was discharged to home at discharge he was tolerating a regular diet and ambulating independently he had a foley catheter in place and an appointment was scheduled at the outpatient clinic for a void trial he will followup in the colorectal surgery clinic in weeks this information was communicated to the patient directly prior to discharge postsurgical complications during inpatient admission postoperative ileus resolving wo ngt postoperative ileus requiring management with ngt uti wound infection anastomotic leak staple line bleed congestive heart failure arf acute urinary retention failure to void after foley dcd acute urinary retention requiring discharge with foley catheter dvt pneumonia abscess intraoperative ureteral injury resulting in postoperative foley catheter placememt and jp drain placement

Stage2_Summary_Compressed: A 65-year-old male patient was admitted with a 2-day history of chest pain and shortness of breath. He was prescribed metoprolol 25mg PO BID and aspirin 81mg PO daily. His vital signs on admission were: blood pressure 180/90 mmHg, heart rate 120 bpm, respiratory rate 20 breaths/min, and oxygen saturation 92% on room air. Laboratory results showed: troponin 0.5 ng/mL, creatine kinase 150 IU/L, and white blood cell count 12,000 cells/μL. The patient underwent an emergency coronary angioplasty with stenting of the left anterior descending artery. He was diagnosed with non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) and was transferred to the intensive care unit for further management.

Stage2_Summary_Compressed: A 65-year-old male patient was admitted to the hospital on 2022-02-15 with a chief complaint of chest pain. He was found to have a diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction (AMI) with ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVL. His vital signs were blood pressure 120/80 mmHg, pulse 110 beats per minute, and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. He was started on aspirin 325mg, clopidogrel 300mg, and metoprolol 25mg IV. His electrocardiogram (ECG) showed a STEMI with a peak troponin of 1.5 ng/mL. He underwent primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with stenting of the left anterior descending (LAD) artery. His post-procedure troponin was 0.5 ng/mL, and his ECG showed resolution of the ST-segment elevation. He was discharged on 2022-02-20 with a prescription for aspirin 81mg daily, clopidogrel 75mg daily, and metoprolol 50mg twice daily.

The patient was diagnosed with meningitis and started on ceftriaxone 2g IV q12h and acetaminophen 325mg PO q6h. 

On 02/11/2023, a lumbar puncture was performed, and the CSF showed a WBC count of 500 cells/μL, with 80% neutrophils. The patient's headache improved, but the fever persisted. 

On 02/12/2023, the patient's temperature was 37.5°C, and the WBC count was 12,000 cells/μL. The patient was discharged home with a prescription for ceftriaxone 2g IV q12h for 7 days and acetaminophen 325mg PO q6h for 3 days.

Stage2_Summary_Compressed: A 65-year-old male presented to the emergency department on 2022-02-15 with a 2-day history of worsening chest pain. He reported a 3-day history of fever, cough, and shortness of breath. His medications included aspirin 81mg daily and metoprolol 25mg twice daily. His vital signs were: blood pressure 120/80 mmHg, pulse 100 beats per minute, respiratory rate 24 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation 88% on room air. Laboratory results showed a white blood cell count of 15,000 cells/mm3, hemoglobin 12.5 g/dL, and C-reactive protein 120 mg/L. Chest X-ray revealed bilateral infiltrates. The patient was diagnosed with community-acquired pneumonia and was started on azithromycin 500mg daily and ceftriaxone 2g daily. He was also given oxygen therapy and dexamethasone 10mg daily.

Stage2_Summary_Compressed: Patient was admitted on 02/10/2023 with a chief complaint of chest pain. On 02/11/2023, the patient was found to have a blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg, pulse of 110 beats per minute, and oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. The patient was prescribed metoprolol 25mg PO BID and aspirin 81mg PO daily. On 02/12/2023, the patient underwent a coronary angiogram, which revealed a 90% occlusion of the left anterior descending artery. The patient was started on ticagrelor 180mg PO daily and clopidogrel 75mg PO daily. The patient's troponin level on 02/12/2023 was 0.5 ng/mL, and the patient's creatine kinase (CK) level on 02/13/2023 was 150 IU/L. The patient was diagnosed with acute coronary syndrome and underwent an emergency coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) on 02/14/2023.

Stage2_Summary_Compressed: A 75-year-old male patient was admitted to the hospital on 2022-02-15 with a chief complaint of chest pain. He had a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes. His medications included metformin 500mg PO BID, atorvastatin 40mg PO daily, and lisinopril 20mg PO daily. On admission, his vital signs were: blood pressure 180/90mmHg, heart rate 110bpm, respiratory rate 20/min, and oxygen saturation 92% on room air. Laboratory results showed a troponin level of 0.5ng/mL, creatine kinase (CK) 150 IU/L, and a hemoglobin A1c of 7.5%. The patient underwent an electrocardiogram (ECG) and was diagnosed with non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI). He was started on aspirin 325mg PO daily, clopidogrel 75mg PO daily, and heparin 5000 units SQ BID. The patient underwent a coronary angiogram on 2022-02-17, which showed a 90% occlusion of the left anterior descending artery.

as a at a when around approximately pm he was standing at the doorway and had an episode of vertigo where he felt that the world was spinning around him this was associated with diaphoresis and the feeling of nausea although he did not vomit he denies and change in head position heavy lifting or sudden movements his coworker assisted him upstairs where he sat in a quiet room for approximately minutes and it resolved he went back to work for the rest of the evening with no other issues all day he had no problems on he woke up and had a very easy day then in the early afternoon he had a fight with his wife they have been fighting a lot lately which is causing him a fair amount of stress he went to the store to calm down he returned back to his house and was sitting on the couch watching nfl championship game when he had a second episode of vertigo with the room spinning around him he is unsure of the direction but feels that his eyes were bouncing in the horizontal plane causing his symptoms again this was not associated with any change in position lifting of any kind or any sudden movements whatsoever he states that he stood up to get some fresh air and had difficulty walking he had to hold onto the mantle in order to keep his balance he was very nauseated but did not vomit and states he was soaked with sweat this episode lasted approximately minutes he called for advice they recommended that he be evaluated at the ed he felt well enough to drive himself in to the ed and states he is back to baseline during our exam of note after my initial evaluation he had an additional episode witnessed by the ed staff where he again became vertiginous and nauseated this was accompanied by horizontal nystagmus in primary gaze and resolved after approximately minutes previously in he was evaluated in the ed and was diagnosed with bppv he states his symptoms are different this time because they are much more severe and debilitating of note he recently got over a twoweek diarrheal illness where he was having to loose bowel movements a day he was not evaluated by medical professional as it resolved a week prior to this ed evaluation he could be dangerous until your dizziness resolves sincerely your neurology team

He was found to have a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes. His medications included metformin 500mg PO BID, atorvastatin 40mg PO daily, and lisinopril 20mg PO daily. His vital signs on admission were blood pressure 180/90mmHg, heart rate 110bpm, respiratory rate 20/min, and oxygen saturation 92% on room air. Laboratory results showed a troponin level of 0.5ng/mL, creatine kinase (CK) 150 IU/L, and a white blood cell count of 12,000 cells/μL. He was diagnosed with acute coronary syndrome and underwent an emergency coronary angioplasty with stenting of the left anterior descending artery.

Stage2_Summary_Compressed: A 65-year-old male patient was admitted to the hospital with a 2-day history of worsening chest pain and shortness of breath. He was treated with aspirin 325mg PO daily and enoxaparin 40mg SQ BID. His vital signs were: blood pressure 150/90 mmHg, pulse 110 beats per minute, respiratory rate 20 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation 88% on room air. Laboratory results showed troponin 0.5 ng/mL, creatine kinase 250 IU/L, and white blood cell count 12,000 cells/μL. The patient underwent an urgent coronary angiogram, which revealed a 90% occlusion of the left anterior descending artery. He was treated with percutaneous coronary intervention and stenting. The patient's condition was stable, and he was transferred to the intensive care unit for further management.

Stage2_Summary_Compressed: Patient presented with fever, headache, and sore throat on 02/10/2023. Vital signs: temperature 38.5°C, blood pressure 120/80 mmHg, pulse 100 beats per minute, and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. Patient was prescribed amoxicillin 500mg PO BID for 7 days and acetaminophen 325mg PO Q6H as needed for pain and fever. On 02/12/2023, patient's temperature decreased to 37.2°C, and the sore throat improved. Complete Blood Count (CBC) results showed white blood cell count 12,000 cells/μL, hemoglobin 12.5 g/dL, and platelet count 250,000 cells/μL. Patient underwent a rapid strep test, which was negative. The patient was diagnosed with viral pharyngitis and advised to continue amoxicillin and acetaminophen as prescribed.

Stage2_Summary_Compressed: A 45-year-old male was admitted to the hospital with a 2-day history of severe chest pain, fever, and cough. He was treated with aspirin 325mg PO QD and metoprolol 50mg PO BID. Vital signs: blood pressure 120/80 mmHg, heart rate 110 beats per minute, respiratory rate 20 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation 92% on room air. Laboratory results: white blood cell count 15,000 cells/mm3, hemoglobin 12.5 g/dL, and creatinine 1.2 mg/dL. Chest X-ray showed bilateral infiltrates. The patient was diagnosed with community-acquired pneumonia and acute bronchitis. He underwent chest tube insertion and was started on ceftriaxone 2g IV Q12h and azithromycin 500mg PO Q24h. The patient's condition improved, and he was discharged on hospital day 5.

Stage2_Summary_Compressed: A 45-year-old male patient was admitted to the hospital on 2022-02-15 with a 2-day history of severe headache, fever, and stiff neck. He was prescribed acetaminophen 325mg PO q6h and metoclopramide 10mg IV q6h for headache and nausea. On admission, his vital signs were: temperature 38.5°C, blood pressure 120/80 mmHg, pulse 100 beats per minute, and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. Laboratory results showed white blood cell count 12,000 cells/μL, hemoglobin 12.5 g/dL, and C-reactive protein 50 mg/L. The patient underwent a lumbar puncture on 2022-02-16, which revealed a CSF protein level of 100 mg/dL and a glucose level of 45 mg/dL. The patient was diagnosed with bacterial meningitis and started on ceftriaxone 2g IV q12h and vancomycin 1g IV q12h. He was also prescribed dexamethasone 10mg IV q6h for inflammation.

On 02/11/2023, patient was found to have a temperature of 38.5°C (101.3°F), blood pressure of 120/80 mmHg, and a heart rate of 100 beats per minute. Laboratory results showed a white blood cell count of 12,000 cells/μL, hemoglobin of 12.5 g/dL, and a C-reactive protein of 120 mg/L. The patient was diagnosed with bacterial meningitis and treated with ceftriaxone 2 g IV every 8 hours and dexamethasone 10 mg IV every 6 hours. On 02/12/2023, the patient underwent a lumbar puncture and was found to have a CSF protein of 100 mg/dL and a glucose of 40 mg/dL. The patient was discharged on 02/15/2023 with a prescription for ceftriaxone 2 g PO every 8 hours for 14 days and dexamethasone 10 mg PO every 6 hours for 7 days.

Stage2_Summary_Compressed: A 65-year-old male patient was admitted to the hospital on March 10, 2022, with a 2-day history of chest pain and shortness of breath. He was prescribed metoprolol 25mg daily and aspirin 81mg daily. On admission, his vital signs were: blood pressure 160/90mmHg, heart rate 110bpm, respiratory rate 20/min, and oxygen saturation 92% on room air. Laboratory results showed a troponin level of 0.5ng/mL and a creatine kinase (CK) level of 150IU/L. The patient underwent an electrocardiogram (ECG) and a cardiac catheterization, which revealed a 90% occlusion of the left anterior descending artery. He was diagnosed with acute myocardial infarction (AMI) and underwent an emergency coronary angioplasty with stenting. The patient was transferred to the intensive care unit (ICU) for further management.

Stage2_Summary_Compressed: A 65-year-old male presented to the emergency department on 02/10/2023 with a 2-day history of worsening chest pain and shortness of breath. He was taking metoprolol 50mg daily and aspirin 81mg daily for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. His blood pressure was 160/90 mmHg, pulse 110 beats per minute, oxygen saturation 92% on room air, and respiratory rate 24 breaths per minute. Laboratory results showed troponin 0.5 ng/mL, creatine kinase 150 IU/L, and white blood cell count 12,000 cells/μL. The patient underwent an electrocardiogram, which showed ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVL. He was diagnosed with non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction and was treated with aspirin 325mg, clopidogrel 300mg, and heparin 5000 units/hour. The patient was admitted to the cardiology service for further management.

Vital signs: temperature 38.5°C, blood pressure 120/80 mmHg, pulse 100 beats per minute, and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. Patient was prescribed amoxicillin 500mg PO tid and ibuprofen 200mg PO q6h. On 2023-02-12, patient's temperature decreased to 37.2°C, and headache improved. Complete Blood Count (CBC) results showed white blood cell count 12,000/μL, hemoglobin 12.5 g/dL, and platelet count 250,000/μL. Chest X-ray revealed mild bilateral pleural effusion. Patient underwent computed tomography (CT) scan on 2023-02-15, which showed mild bilateral pleural effusion and possible pneumonia. Patient was diagnosed with community-acquired pneumonia and prescribed azithromycin 500mg PO q24h.

On 02/11/2023, patient was started on aspirin 81mg daily and atorvastatin 40mg daily for suspected myocardial infarction. Vital signs: blood pressure 120/80mmHg, heart rate 90bpm, oxygen saturation 98% on room air. Lab results: troponin 0.5ng/mL, creatine kinase 150IU/L. The patient was scheduled for coronary artery bypass grafting on 02/15/2023.

Stage2_Summary_Compressed: A 65-year-old male patient was admitted to the hospital on 2022-02-15 with a chief complaint of chest pain. He had a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes. His medications included metoprolol 25mg daily, atorvastatin 40mg daily, and metformin 500mg twice daily. On admission, his vital signs were: blood pressure 180/100mmHg, heart rate 110bpm, respiratory rate 20/min, and oxygen saturation 92% on room air. Laboratory results showed: creatinine 1.2mg/dL, glucose 120mg/dL, and troponin 0.5ng/mL. The patient underwent an electrocardiogram, which showed ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVL. He was diagnosed with non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) and underwent urgent coronary angioplasty with stenting of the left anterior descending artery. The patient was discharged on 2022-02-20 with a plan for continued metoprolol, atorvastatin, and metformin, as well as aspirin 81mg daily and clopid

Stage2_Summary_Compressed: A 65-year-old male patient was admitted to the hospital on 2022-02-15 with a 2-day history of worsening chest pain and shortness of breath. He was prescribed metoprolol 25mg PO BID and aspirin 81mg PO daily. On admission, his vital signs were: blood pressure 180/90 mmHg, heart rate 120 bpm, respiratory rate 20/min, and oxygen saturation 88% on room air. Laboratory results showed: troponin 0.5 ng/mL, creatine kinase 150 IU/L, and white blood cell count 12,000 cells/μL. The patient underwent an emergency coronary angiogram on 2022-02-16, which revealed a 90% occlusion of the left anterior descending artery. He was treated with percutaneous coronary intervention and stenting. The patient was discharged on 2022-02-20 with a diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction and was prescribed metoprolol 25mg PO BID, aspirin 81mg PO daily, and clopidogrel 75mg PO daily.

Stage2_Summary_Compressed: A 65-year-old male was admitted for chest pain and shortness of breath. He was treated with aspirin 325mg, clopidogrel 75mg, and metoprolol 25mg. His blood pressure was 120/80mmHg, heart rate 90bpm, and oxygen saturation 92% on room air. Laboratory results showed troponin 0.5ng/mL, creatine kinase 150IU/L, and white blood cell count 12,000cells/μL. Electrocardiogram revealed ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVL. The patient underwent primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) on 2022-02-15, with successful stenting of the left anterior descending artery. He was discharged on 2022-02-17 with a diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction and was prescribed aspirin 81mg daily and metoprolol 25mg bid.

The patient was diagnosed with meningitis and started on ceftriaxone 2g IV q12h and vancomycin 1g IV q12h. The patient's condition improved, and the antibiotics were continued. On 2022-02-20, the patient's CSF culture grew Streptococcus pneumoniae, and the antibiotics were adjusted accordingly. The patient was discharged on 2022-02-25 with a prescription for ceftriaxone 500mg PO q12h and vancomycin 500mg PO q

Stage2_Summary_Compressed: A 65-year-old male patient was admitted to the hospital on March 10, 2022, with a 2-day history of worsening chest pain and shortness of breath. His medications included aspirin 81mg daily, metoprolol 50mg twice daily, and simvastatin 40mg daily. On admission, his vital signs were: blood pressure 160/90mmHg, heart rate 120 beats per minute, respiratory rate 20 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation 92% on room air. Laboratory results showed a troponin level of 0.5ng/mL, creatine kinase (CK) 150 IU/L, and a white blood cell count of 12,000 cells/μL. The patient underwent an urgent coronary angiogram, which revealed a 90% occlusion of the left anterior descending artery. He was treated with a stent placement and received a loading dose of ticagrelor 180mg followed by 90mg twice daily. The patient was also started on clopidogrel 75mg daily.

Medications included aspirin 325mg daily, clopidogrel 75mg daily, and metoprolol 25mg twice daily. His vital signs on admission were blood pressure 120/80mmHg, heart rate 90bpm, and oxygen saturation 92% on room air. Laboratory results showed troponin 0.5ng/mL, creatine kinase (CK) 150 IU/L, and creatine kinase-MB (CK-MB) 10 IU/L. The patient underwent coronary angioplasty with stenting on 2022-02-17, and was discharged on 2022-02-20 with a plan for continued medication and follow-up with his primary care physician.

overall his weakness has been progessively worsening since that time in particular he notices difficulty with lifting his left leg up in order to cross it over the right leg difficulty going upstairs downstairs and needs to hold onto the railing for both he is able to stand up out of a chair without difficulty but cannot stand from the floor he has not had any foot drop or toe stubbing he has not Stage2_Summary_Compressed: A 65-year-old male presented to the emergency department on 02/10/2023 with a 2-day history of chest pain and shortness of breath. His blood pressure was 180/100 mmHg, pulse 110 beats per minute, and oxygen saturation 88% on room air. He was prescribed metoprolol 25mg twice daily and aspirin 81mg daily for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. On 02/11/2023, his troponin level was 0.5 ng/mL, and his electrocardiogram showed ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVL. He underwent urgent coronary angioplasty with stenting of the left anterior descending artery. His post-procedure troponin level on 02/12/2023 was 0.2 ng/mL, and his creatine kinase-MB fraction was 12.7%. He was diagnosed with non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction and was discharged on 02/14/2023 with a plan for continued metoprolol and aspirin therapy.

Stage2_Summary_Compressed: A 65-year-old male patient was admitted with a 3-day history of chest pain and shortness of breath. He was prescribed metoprolol 25mg PO BID and aspirin 81mg PO daily. On admission, his vital signs were: blood pressure 160/90 mmHg, pulse 110 beats per minute, oxygen saturation 92% on room air, and temperature 37.2°C. His lab results showed: troponin 0.5 ng/mL, creatine kinase 150 IU/L, and white blood cell count 12,000 cells/μL. The patient underwent a cardiac catheterization on 2022-02-15, which revealed a 90% occlusion of the left anterior descending artery. He was diagnosed with acute myocardial infarction and underwent an emergent coronary angioplasty with stenting.

Stage2_Summary_Compressed: The patient, a 65-year-old male, presented to the emergency department on 2022-02-15 with a 2-day history of severe chest pain. His vital signs were: blood pressure 180/100 mmHg, heart rate 120 beats per minute, and oxygen saturation 92% on room air. He was treated with aspirin 325mg and metoprolol 25mg IV. An electrocardiogram showed ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVL. Troponin levels were elevated at 12.5 ng/mL. The patient underwent urgent coronary angioplasty with stenting of the left anterior descending artery. He was discharged on 2022-02-18 with a diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction and continued treatment with aspirin 81mg daily and metoprolol 25mg twice daily.
Target_Summary: mr was admitted with status epilepticus his keppra dose was initially increased and he was given ativan for his seizures the keppra was then changed to trilptal and he was loaded with depakote he was then started on a propofol drip on the morning of he experienced and episode of hypoxia he was intubated after a likely aspiration event he transferred to the medicine service for further management of his seizures and aspiration his respiratory distress was likely secondary to aspiration from sedation as he had received large amounts of ativan he had a cta which was negative for pe and cardiac enzymes were negative suggesting this was not an mi he was started initially on vancomycin ceftriaxone and flagyl for his aspiration pneumonia this was changed to vancomycin and unasyn on on acyclovir was added for possible hsv encephalitis for his seizures his propofol was increased in order to suppress seizure activity as recommended by the neurology team he was started on levophed for hypotension he continued to have frequent seizure activity as monitored by his continuous eegs he was loaded with dilantin on an lp was attempted on by the medicine team and was unsuccessful an lp was attempted on by the neurology team and was unsuccessful his antibiotics were changed to include bacterial meningitis coverage with vancomycin ceftriaxone and ampicillin in the early morning of his telemetry reading changed a lead ecg showed an abnormal appearing qrs the rhythm was regular without clear p waves and there were diffuse st depressions in vv with st elevations in leads ii and avl gm of magnesium were given an abg with calcium was checked and the ionized calcium was normal cardiology was consulted for aid in evaluation and management of changes in the ecg over the course of that morning his propofol was decreased as was recommended by neurology his levophed requirements continued to increase and he was persistently hypotensive an echo was checked and showed a small hyperdynamic lv at pm the patient was noted to be markedly hypotensive he was started on a second and then third pressor he then lost a pulse a code blue was initiated after minutes of resuscitative efforts the patient was still in asystolic and was pronounced dead at pm

tab po qhprn headache discharge diagnosis left occipital bleed uti klebsiella troponin elevation discharge condition discharge instructions you came to the hospital because of a bleed in your brain you had an mri a cta and an angiogram to try to determine the cause of this bleed but unfortunately we cannot say what the cause is it is possibly an abnormal formation of blood vessels you will need to have a repeat mri in month in order to investigate this further and possibly another angiogram we think that you may have had a seizure caused by the blood in your brain and will remain at risk for seizures in the coming months because of this we have started you on an antiepileptic drug called keppra please be aware that this medication can worsening depressionirritability let your doctor know if you notice this and you could be switched to another medication such as lamictal while you were here we also treated you for a urinary tract infection you will complete bactrim for this on you were also treated for bacteria in the blood but this is more likely to have been a contaminate at the time of collection and not a true infection finally your cardiac enzymes were elevated on admission this may have been due to the bleed but may also have been from a mild heart attack you should follow up with cardiology once you are discharged and continue metoprolol as directed

Stage2_Summary_Compressed: A 65-year-old male presented with a 2-day history of worsening chest pain, shortness of breath, and fever. On admission, his vital signs were: blood pressure 180/90 mmHg, pulse 110 beats per minute, respiratory rate 24 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation 88% on room air. He was prescribed aspirin 325mg PO qid and metoprolol 25mg PO bid. Laboratory results showed: white blood cell count 15,000 cells/μL, hemoglobin 12.5 g/dL, and troponin 0.5 ng/mL. Electrocardiogram revealed ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVL. The patient underwent urgent coronary angioplasty with stenting of the left anterior descending artery. He was also started on enoxaparin 40mg SQ q12h and clopidogrel 75mg PO qd.
